episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on April 18, 2023 with Charles T. Johnson regarding a motor vehicle accident. The intake was conducted by Brandon French. The attorney listed is Aaron Whaley, though the client is currently not represented by an attorney. The case arises in Jefferson County, with the incident having occurred at the intersection of 22nd Street and Main Street. The LMPD case number is 8023029550.

The incident date is April 17, 2023 at 4:00 AM, with the time of the accident listed as 11:00 AM. The client was traveling down Main Street when the defendant, who ran a red light, t-boned the client, pushing him off the road into a parking lot. Two vehicles were involved: the client’s 2003 Ford Crown Victoria and a black Jeep described as the defendant’s vehicle. The location was 22nd and Main in Jefferson County. Weather and road conditions were sunny and dry. The damage to the client’s vehicle was to the front and passenger side, while the other vehicle sustained front damage. The fault factor given is that the defendant ran a red light and t-boned the client.

Police attended the scene, and EMS also responded. The EMS team transported the client to the hospital. The client reported chest pain, as well as neck and back pain. He went to the emergency department (ER) or urgent care and is currently treating with a doctor.

Insurance and claims information: the client’s vehicle has insurance, and the driver’s insurance information is on file. The claim status is pending, including the bodily injury (BI) claim status. The defendant’s vehicle is described as a black Jeep. The case type is motor vehicle accident. The client was injured and has had medical treatment for those injuries. The incident is attributed to someone else’s fault, and the client is employed full-time, earning $12 per hour.

A message was sent to you regarding record request #23-10405:

Specific to your request for body/dash camera video: I have located video
responsive to your request. Pursuant to KRS 61.872(5) and due to the large

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T Johnson. This note records correspondence related to a motor vehicle accident case involving Charles T. Johnson on April 18, 2023.

On Friday, October 6, 2023, at 13:32:47 -0400, Jessa Galosmo of Whaley Law Firm forwarded an external message about Louisville Metro Government public records request #23-10405 to Justin Chumbley. The message included the line: “No photos were taken as well.” The forwarded thread then continued with a message from Louisville Metro Government Public Records, dated October 6, 2023, at 1:17 PM, subject: Louisville Metro Government public records request #23-10405. The public records office stated that they located video responsive to the request for body/dash camera footage. However, under KRS 61.872(5) and due to the large volume of pending video requests, the video is currently in active storage and unavailable. They advised to allow up to at least six months (by April 5, 2024) to prepare and provide any records they may possess. The unit processes requests in the order they are received and currently has an estimated 400 requests ahead of this one. Each request varies in the number of videos, their length, and the amount of redaction. If the videos become available earlier, the requester will be notified.

The message provided a link to view the request: https://louisvilleglobalmetrogov-ky.nextrequest.com/requests/23-10405. It also notes that questions about the request can be addressed by replying to the email or signing in to contact staff at Louisville Metro Government, and that technical support can be found on their help page.

The correspondence ends with the sign-off from Jessa Galosmo of the Whaley Law Firm, including her contact details: Ph: (502) 357-9975; Fax: (502) 364-9363.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T. Johnson.

In April 2024, a follow-up matter regarding Charles Johnson’s medical records from his motor vehicle accident case was handled through a series of email exchanges between The Whaley Law Firm and Integra Medical Imaging. On April 9, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Adriana Medina at Integra Medical Imaging to acknowledge the clarification and the Certification. In her message, she thanked Adriana for the clarification and the certification, and she signed off with her title, the firm’s address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971) and office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), her email (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), and a note to please “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

The email thread shows several exchanges within a short window. In one message dated Tue, Apr 9, 2024 at 1:34?PM, Adriana stated that she had attached signed forms and that there was no itemized billing for Mr. Johnson, clarifying that they do not bill the patient. She explained that Integra Medical Imaging leases its services to a chiropractic office and that the chiropractic office should have an itemized bill for Mr. Johnson. Her signature block identified Integra Medical Imaging and included the following details: 2137 Dixie Highway, Louisville, KY 40210; Phone: 859-757-2297; Fax: 859-757-2042; website: www.integradx.com.

Earlier in the thread, in an email sent on the same day, 1:18?PM, Adriana had provided the actual medical records and stated: “Good afternoon Sarena, Attached are all medical records Integra Medical Imaging has for patient Charles Johnson 04-01-1952. We did not bill patient directly, please contact referring chiropractic office for additional information. Please let me know if you have any questions.” The signature block for this message again listed Integra Medical Imaging with the address and contact information noted above.

Following Adriana’s 1:18?PM message, Sarena replied at 1:21?PM with a brief acknowledgment: “Thank you so much Adriana!” Her signature block again included The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and the note to please use the new email address.

Subsequently, at 1:25 PM, Sarena sent another message explaining that, upon review of the attached medical records, she did not see a Certification Form or Billing. She stated that she had attached a certification form for Adriana’s convenience and requested that the form be completed and returned to The Whaley Law Firm along with the itemized billing for Mr. Johnson.

Shortly after, at 1:34?PM, Adriana replied with the signed forms and reiterated that there is no itemized billing for Mr. Johnson, as they do not bill the patient. She noted that Integra Medical Imaging leases its services to the chiropractic office and that the chiropractic office should have the itemized bill for Mr. Johnson. Her message concluded with her signature block, which again listed Integra Medical Imaging’s contact details.

In summary, the exchange between The Whaley Law Firm and Integra Medical Imaging in this case involved provision of all medical records for Charles Johnson (born 04-01-1952), confirmation that the patient was not billed directly, and a request for an itemized billing and a completed Certification Form to accompany the records. The parties cited that the itemized bill should come from the referring chiropractic office, to whom the services were leased.

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T Johnson. This reflects an email exchange on April 9, 2024 between Integra Medical Imaging and The Whaley Law Firm regarding Charles Johnson’s medical records connected to his motor vehicle accident case.

On April 9, 2024 at 1:18 PM, Adriana Medina of Integra Medical Imaging sent an email to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, attaching all medical records Integra has for patient Charles Johnson, born April 1, 1952. Adriana noted that Integra did not bill the patient directly and asked that the requesting party contact the referring chiropractic office for additional information. Her message included her contact details: Integra Medical Imaging, 2137 Dixie Highway, Louisville, KY 40210; Phone 859-757-2297; Fax 859-757-2042; www.integradx.com.

Sarena Tuttle replied at 1:21 PM, thanking Adriana. Sarena identified herself as Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line was 502-357-9971, with the office line at 502-583-4022 ext 104, and her email listed as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting that this was her NEW email address.

In a follow-up at 1:25 PM the same day, Sarena stated that, upon review of the attached medical records, she did not see a Certification Form or Billing. She attached a Certification Form for Adriana’s convenience and requested that the form be completed and returned to The Whaley Law Firm along with the itemized billing for Mr. Johnson.

Later that same day, at 1:34 PM, Adriana sent another email re: Charles Johnson Medical Records. She reported that she had attached signed forms and reiterated that there is no itemized billing for Mr. Johnson, as they do not bill patients directly. She explained that Integra leases its services to a chiropractic office, and that the itemized bill for Mr. Johnson should be held by that referring chiropractic office. She closed by signing her name and providing her contact information again: Adriana Medina, Integra Medical Imaging, 2137 Dixie Highway, Louisville, KY 40210; Phone: 859-757-2297; Fax: 859-757-2042; www.integradx.com.

Signatures and contact details included in the thread show:

- Adriana Medina, Integra Medical Imaging, with the address, phone, fax, and website listed above. 
- Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Direct line 502-357-9971, Office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting it as the NEW email address). Her signature also included both “D” and “O” phone details and reiterated her role as Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager.

Key facts preserved across the exchange:
- Case reference: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023; patient: Charles Johnson (DOB 04-01-1952).
- Integra Medical Imaging provided medical records and stated they do not bill patients directly; itemized billing is expected to be handled by the referring chiropractic office.
- The Whaley Law Firm requested a Certification Form and the itemized billing for Mr. Johnson, attaching a Certification Form for convenience.
- Email addresses and contact details for both parties were included and updated in the thread.

In the Jefferson Circuit case 24-CI-002475, NCP for eFiler, the envelope number is 7797647. The Kentucky Court of Justice eFiling system processed and ACCEPTED the filing on April 23, 2024, at 11:58 AM Eastern Time. The eFiler listed was WHALEY, AARON GREGORY (ATTORNEY FOR PLAINTIFF). The court identified the case caption as JOHNSON, CHARLES VS. LOWE, ROBERT.

The electronically mailed notice was sent to Whaley, Aaron Gregory at agwhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com. There were no scheduled events associated with this filing. The following documents were included in this eFiling: COMPLAINT / PETITION and INTERROGATORIES & REQUEST FOR PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS.

Additional details can be accessed at https://kcoj.kycourts.net/efiling/Dashboard/Receipt?caseid=7797647, and the documents can be viewed at https://kcoj.kycourts.net/eFilingRetrieval/Home/Package?id=7AAD77CF-1F7C-488E-B2F5-5E5EE2B3F653.

The message was addressed to Sarena Tuttle at the Whaley Law Firm (Sarena@whaleylawfirm.com).

In the body of the message, Nicola Greene provided her contact information: fax number 502-627-1806 and email nicola.greene@uoflhealth.org, along with a reference to the UofL Health website at UofLHealth.org. The message also carries a Confidentiality Disclaimer, stating that the communication and any attachments are confidential and intended only for the named recipient(s); they may contain information that is privileged or exempt from disclosure under applicable law, including PHI protected under HIPAA. Tuttle and included the firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

In addition to that initial outreach, the record shows a follow-up communication on Tuesday, June 11, 2024, at 1:59 PM (-0400). In this message, Sarena M. Tuttle again wrote to Gail at Starlite Chiropractic with the subject line “Re: Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Charles Johnson DOB 04/01/1952.” The content was a request to provide a status update on the certified medical records and billing. The email again carried Sarena’s signature block, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address, the same telephone numbers, and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the parenthetical note “(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS).”

Charles T. Johnson is the client in the matter titled Johnson v. Lowe, arising from a motor vehicle accident on April 18, 2023. This case is reflected in the file name Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. The notes summarize recent email communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, regarding discovery in the case.

On June 25, 2024, at approximately 4:17 PM, Amy Romine, a paralegal at Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, sent an email stating, “Please see the attached letter, answer, and discovery requests from Ms. Johnson.” Her message included the Dilbeck & Myers contact information: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone 502-595-6500; Fax 502-595-6504. The email was addressed to Mary Johnson and Amy Romine, with the broader distribution including agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com and CharlesJohnsonZ3709312@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and it related to attachments from Ms. Johnson.

The following day, Wednesday, June 26, 2024, at 10:04:32 AM Eastern Time, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, replied to counsel. He confirmed receipt of the recipient’s Answer and Discovery Requests, and noted that the discovery requests had been served contemporaneously with the Complaint. He stated his desire to confirm that the client had received these discovery requests and mentioned that a Word copy of the requests was attached for convenience. He closed by offering to provide anything else that might be needed. His contact details were listed as The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207.

The email from Bryce Koon also included a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer: “This electronic message is intended only for the named recipient. It may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information. If you have received this message or any attachment in error, you are instructed to contact The Whaley Law Firm and advise in this regard, no waiver of any privilege shall be applicable, and you are instructed that you should not use the information contained herein or forward it to any third person not intended to receive it.”

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. The client is Charles T Johnson, involved in a motor vehicle accident on April 18, 2023, with the matter referenced as CHARLES TIMOTHY JOHNSON - 300-0238527-2023. The file is currently in litigation.

On July 30, 2024, at 11:30:55 a.m. Eastern Time, an email with the subject Re: CHARLES TIMOTHY JOHNSON - 300-0238527-2023 was sent from Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm (agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com) to Amy Cox (Cox.Amy@aoins.com), with copies to Sarena Whaley (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) and KentuckyPIP.Clm@aoins.com. In the message, Whaley stated that because the file is in litigation, he is not in a position to direct payment at this time. He offered two options: forward the remaining benefits to his office to be held in trust, or keep them until the claim is resolved.

Earlier that same day, at about 11:09 a.m., Amy Cox replied: “Good morning. Please see attached request for an update on your client, Charles Johnson, with regard to the accident on 04/18/2023. I am in need of a treatment status update and updated direction for PIP benefits. Mr. Johnson has $2,350 remaining in PIP benefits. Please advise if you are directing payment to any of the attached, unpaid bills. I appreciate your help.” The reply referenced an attached request for an update and included multiple images in the email. Amy Cox signed as a Claims Representative for Kentucky Regional PIP, with contact details: p: 800-346-0346 ext. 54610; f: 517-886-8754; e: KentuckyPIP.clm@aoins.com; hours: 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. EST, and a note about the Customer Center.

Signatures at the bottom of the thread show Aaron Whaley of Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-583-4022, and the email correspondence between the Whaley Law Firm and Amy Cox reflects the ongoing PIP and litigation communications related to the Charles T Johnson matter.

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T. Johnson. This record covers a series of email exchanges concerning discovery responses in the motor-vehicle-accident case Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe, 24-CI-002475, which arises from the 4/18/2023 MVA.

On September 3, 2024, at 10:18 AM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an external message to counsel for the opposing party regarding the case. The email was addressed to Mary [last name] of Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC (mary@dilbeckandmyers.com) and was CC’d to Amy Romine (amy@dilbeckandmyers.com) and to Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 via the Filevine project email address CharlesJohnsonZ3709312@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, with Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) also copied. The subject line read: EXTERNAL MESSAGE Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (24-CI-002475). In the body, Koon stated that he was following up on the client’s outstanding discovery responses that had been served with the Plaintiff’s Complaint, noting that he had attempted to reach out several times without receiving a response. He warned that if no response was received, he would be forced to file a motion to compel, and he requested any update. He closed with his name and contact details: W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The message carried a standard confidentiality or privilege notice typical of such communications, which stated that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information, and if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and refrain from using or forwarding the information.

On September 6, 2024, Mary [last name] of Dilbeck & Myers replied to Bryce Koon. She apologized for the delay, explaining that she did have the discovery responses but needed to type them up and format them. She noted she had been in trial and described the “digging out” as the worst part of trial, adding that she would get the responses ready hopefully the following week and thanked Bryce for his patience. Mary provided her contact information: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-595-6500; fax 502-595-6504. The message included a standard confidentiality notice: “NOTICE: This electronic mail transmission is for the use of the named individual or entity to which it is directed and may contain information that is privileged or confidential. It is not to be transmitted to or received by anyone other than the named addressee (or a person authorized to deliver it to the named addressee). It is not to be copied or forwarded to any unauthorized persons. If you have received this electronic mail transmission in error, delete it from your system without copying or forwarding it, and notify the sender of the error by replying via email or by calling Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC at (502) 595-6500, so that our address record can be corrected.”

The September 3, 2024 message from Bryce that initiated this thread is also reflected in the chain. In that prior message, Bryce reiterated the request for the client’s discovery responses, stated that the responses had been served with the Plaintiff’s Complaint, and warned that failure to respond would result in a motion to compel. The message included the same contact details for Bryce Koon and The Whaley Law Firm as noted above, along with the same Filevine project address for the Charles Johnson matter and the same confidential notice.

Finally, on September 18, 2024, at 2:56 PM (GMT-04:00), Bryce Koon sent another follow-up to counsel. The message began, “Good afternoon counsel, Any update on your client’s discovery responses?” and concluded with thanks in advance. It again carried Bryce Koon’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email carried the same standard confidentiality or privilege notice as the previous messages, indicating the restricted and privileged nature of the communication and directing recipients who were not the intended addressees to contact the sender and refrain from using or forwarding the information.

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T. Johnson.

In the matter of Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (24-CI-002475), the following sequence of external communications took place between counsel in late September 2024. On September 3, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, emailed counsel for the defense regarding the plaintiff’s discovery responses. He noted that the client’s discovery responses had been served with the Plaintiff’s Complaint and stated that if no update was provided, he would be forced to file a motion to compel. The email was addressed to Mary S. Johnson (of Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC) and copied to Amy Romine, the Filevine project email for Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023, and Sarena Tuttle. The Whaley Law Firm listed its office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207. The message carried the standard confidentiality notice common to these communications.

On September 6, 2024, Mary S. Johnson replied. She apologized and said she did have the client’s responses but needed to type them up and format them. She explained she had been in trial and described the discovery task as “the digging out” being the worst part of trial. She indicated she would prepare the materials and have them ready “hopefully next week.” Her signature block included her address at 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, with a phone number of (502) 595-6500 and a fax number of (502) 595-6504, and a confidentiality notice appended to the email.

The exchange continued on September 18, 2024. At 2:57 PM, Bryce Koon followed up again, asking for an update on the client’s discovery responses. In the ensuing message thread, Mary S. Johnson responded later that day, indicating that the discovery responses were ready to go but that she was waiting on the client’s verification. She explained that the client was out of town and had said that if she could send him a DocuSign, he would return it promptly; however, she did not have the technological capability to perform that. Consequently, she anticipated having to wait until the following week to obtain the verification signed. The emails in this portion of the thread included standard confidentiality notices.

Also on September 18, 2024, at approximately 3:01 PM, the same Mary S. Johnson reiterated that the answers were ready but waiting on verification, reiterating the client’s being out of town and his preference for DocuSign, which she could not facilitate, and again noting that she expected to wait until the next week to secure the signed verification. These messages again carried the confidentiality notices typical to the correspondence.

Finally, on September 25, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an external message reiterating the ongoing status and shifting the focus to scheduling. He stated that they were still awaiting the client’s discovery responses and requested that dates in mid- to late October be provided when counsel and the client would be available to proceed with the deposition. The subject of the message remained the same: Re: EXTERNAL MESSAGE Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (24-CI-002475). The email was sent to Mary S. Johnson and was CC’d to Amy Romine, the Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 Filevine Project Email Address, and Sarena Tuttle; it also included the same confidentiality disclaimer.

Throughout the correspondence, the case at issue remains the automobile accident matter (MVA) involving Charles T. Johnson and Robert Lowe, with the deposition currently being scheduled and discovery responses still outstanding as of late September 2024. The communications reference the parties’ respective law firms, the Filevine project email address for the case, and the contact details listed above for The Whaley Law Firm and for Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC.

episodes.natural_language:
In the motor vehicle accident matter of Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (docket 24-CI-002475), Charles T. Johnson is the client. The case is referenced as Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023, with the incident occurring on April 18, 2023. The primary communications presented here are a series of emails between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Mary S. Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, regarding discovery responses and deposition scheduling.

On September 3, 2024, Bryce Koon sent an external message to counsel handling Charles Johnson’s case, asking for an update on the client’s outstanding discovery responses that were served with the plaintiff’s complaint. He noted that he had attempted several times to obtain a response and warned that if he did not hear back, he would be forced to file a motion to compel. He requested dates in mid- to late October when the client and counsel would be available for the deposition.

Mary S. Johnson replied on September 6, 2024. She apologized and stated that she did have the client’s discovery responses but needed to type them up and present them nicely. She explained she had been in trial and described the process of “digging out” as the worst part of trial, adding that she would get the responses ready hopefully next week and thanked Bryce for his patience.

In the subsequent messages, Mary’s communications include her contact information and a standard confidentiality notice. The note shows she was at 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, with phone and fax numbers listed, and that the notice asks recipients to delete and notify if the email was received in error.

On September 18, 2024, Mary wrote again: “Yes. They are ready to go, but I am waiting on his verification. He is out of town and he said if I can send him a DocuSign, he would send it right back. Well, I don’t think I have the technological capabilities to do that. So, I guess I will have to wait until next week to get the verification signed.” This message indicates that the client’s verification was pending and that DocuSign would have been convenient but was not available to her.

Later that same day, September 18, 2024 at 2:57 p.m., Bryce Koon followed up with Mary, asking, “Good afternoon counsel, Any update on your client’s discovery responses?” He again referenced the ongoing status of the discovery responses and requested any available information.

Finally, on September 25, 2024 at 9:24 a.m. (Eastern Time), Bryce sent another external message reiterating that they were still awaiting the client’s discovery responses. He asked to schedule the deposition and requested that Mary provide dates in mid- to late October when she and her client would be available for deposition. He included his contact details for scheduling at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the firm’s phone and fax numbers.

Throughout these exchanges, the subject line consistently referred to the matter: Re: EXTERNAL MESSAGE Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (24-CI-002475). The communications convey a coordinated effort to obtain and finalize discovery materials and to schedule the deposition, with the October timeframe as the target for availability, while discovery responses remained outstanding at the time of the latest messages.

episodes.natural_language:
This note concerns the Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe matter in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 24-CI-002475, in which the client is Charles T. Johnson. The matter involves filings related to a motor vehicle accident dated 4/18/2023. The communications described below come from and between The Whaley Law Firm and the Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC office, with the Filevine project for Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 referenced in the CC line.

On October 8, 2024, at 1:49 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mary S. Johnson at Dilbeck & Myers, with the Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 Filevine project email address included in the CC line. The subject of the email was Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (Jefferson 24-CI-002475). In the body, Bryce stated good morning counsel and asked to review the attachments, noting that they had been filed today in Jefferson Circuit Court. He invited any questions and closed with his contact information and firm details, including The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and phone and fax numbers.

That same day, October 8, 2024, at 4:27 PM, Mary S. Johnson replied. She apologized for the delay, explaining that she had the materials ready for a few days but had been occupied with oral arguments. She indicated that she had changed the date on the certificate to today and invited Bryce to inform her if there were any issues with the attachments. She provided her contact details: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; phone 502-595-6500; fax 502-595-6504. She also included a confidentiality and privileged-information notice stating that the electronic transmission is for the named recipient and may contain privileged or confidential information, and that it should not be copied or forwarded to unauthorized persons. If received in error, she asked the recipient to delete the message and notify Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC at the listed phone number so their address records could be corrected.

The email thread also carried the standard disclaimer common to these communications, affirming that the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged information; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and should not disclose or forward the information.

On October 10, 2024, at 10:31 AM, Bryce Koon again wrote to counsel in the same matter with the subject Re: Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (Jefferson 24-CI-002475). He stated, Good morning counsel, and informed them to please see the attached Notice of Remand filed today. The email bore his signature and the same firm contact details as before (The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207). It also included the standard attorney-client privilege notice reiterating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and should not be shared with unauthorized persons; if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and delete or forward the notice only as appropriate, with no waiver of privilege.

The email from Mary on October 8 contained a separate confidentiality disclaimer, reiterating that the transmission is for the named recipient and may contain privileged or confidential information, not to be copied or forwarded to unauthorized persons, and instructions to delete and notify the sender if received in error, with a contact number for Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC to correct their address record. The thread thus records the filing of a Notice of Remand today in Jefferson Circuit Court, accompanied by prior attachments and the ongoing exchange of due-diligence communications between the parties’ counsel.

The correspondence dated in late October through early November 2024 documents efforts to schedule the deposition of Mr. Lowe and to confirm dates and format for depositions related to the Jeff Cir case.

On October 23, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and the Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mrs. Mary S. Johnson (of Dilbeck & Myers) with the subject Charles Johnson v Robert Lowe - Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475. In that message, Sarena noted that Bryce had previously sent an email on September 25, 2024, following up on Mr. Lowe’s responses to the Plaintiff’s Discovery Request and acknowledged receipt of those responses. However, Bryce had also requested dates on which Mr. Lowe would be available to be deposed, and Sarena asked Mary to provide some available dates for the deposition next month.

Later, on October 28, 2024 at 12:34 PM, Sarena again corresponded with Mary and Amy Romine (also of Dilbeck & Myers) with Bryce and Aaron Whaley CC’d. In this follow-up, Sarena stated that they had requested dates to depose Mr. Lowe on several occasions over the past 30 days but had not yet received any dates to complete the deposition. She urged Mary to provide dates as soon as possible, noting that the holidays were approaching and calendars would fill up quickly. Her message included her signature and contact information, including her new email address, and reaffirmed her role as a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

On November 4, 2024, Mary S. Johnson replied from Dilbeck & Myers. In her message, she stated that Mr. Lowe would be available on November 26 after 2:00 PM. She proposed scheduling Mr. Johnson’s deposition at 1:00 PM and then Mr. Lowe afterward, explaining that this arrangement would keep the proceedings from running too late. She asked whether this schedule would work for Sarena’s client and stated a preference for Zoom, while also indicating a willingness to appear in person if that was preferred. Mary provided her contact details: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, Phone: (502) 595-6500, Fax: (502) 595-6504. A confidentiality notice followed in the message, stating that this electronic transmission is for the named recipient and may contain privileged or confidential information, not to be transmitted to unauthorized persons, and instructing the recipient to delete the message and notify the sender if received in error.

Also in the November 4, 2024 email chain, Sarena responded on the same day at 1:36 PM confirming receipt of Mary’s scheduling proposal and further clarifying the plan. She accepted the November 26, 2024 date, indicated reliance on Zoom as the desired mode of participation, and proposed a one-hour deposition for Mr. Johnson beginning at 1:00 PM, with the understanding that Mr. Lowe would follow after that deposition, all to be conducted on November 26 via Zoom.

The chain then includes the signature of Sarena M. Tuttle, reiterating her role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, along with the firm’s address and contact numbers: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a note to note the new email address.

In sum, the parties coordinated to hold depositions on November 26, 2024, with Mary proposing that Mr. Johnson be deposed at 1:00 PM and Mr. Lowe afterward, all to be conducted by Zoom (though in-person attendance was not ruled out). Sarena subsequently confirmed that Zoom would be suitable and that the Johnson deposition would be one hour starting at 1:00 PM, with Mr. Lowe’s deposition to follow. The correspondence also reflects ongoing efforts to obtain deposition dates for Mr. Lowe and to finalize scheduling in light of the approaching holidays, along with standard confidentiality notices and contact details.

The proposed schedule envisioned Mr. Johnson’s deposition beginning at 1:00 PM for potentially up to an hour, followed by Mr. Lowe’s deposition beginning around 2:30 PM (with a break between sessions), all contingent on mutual agreement. Throughout the correspondence, the emails consistently advised that the transmission contained privileged or confidential information and should not be copied or forwarded to unauthorized recipients.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T Johnson. In the matter of Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475), communications in November 2024 between The Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck & Myers focused on scheduling depositions of the plaintiffs and witnesses.

Starting in late September 2024, Bryce Koon of Dilbeck & Myers emailed following up on Mr. Lowe’s responses to the plaintiff’s discovery request and requested dates on which Mr. Lowe would be available for deposition, asking for dates next month. On October 23, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied, asking Mary to provide some dates next month when Mr. Lowe would be available for deposition. A week later, on October 28, 2024, Sarena sent a further note stating that they had requested deposition dates for Mr. Lowe over the previous 30 days but had not yet received any, and urged Mary to provide dates as soon as possible given the upcoming holidays and calendars filling up.

On November 4, 2024, at 1:36 PM, Mary Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers replied that Mr. Lowe was available on November 26 after 2:00 PM, and that they could arrange for Mr. Johnson to be deposed at 1:00 PM and then depose Mr. Lowe afterward, noting a preference for Zoom but willingness to appear in person if that was preferred. The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena Tuttle responded later the same day at 2:38 PM, confirming that November 26 via Zoom was perfectly fine and asking for confirmation that there would be only a one-hour deposition for Mr. Johnson starting at 1:00 PM.

On November 7, 2024, at 10:03 AM, Mary replied that she typically allocates 1 to 1.5 hours for depositions, and suggested starting Mr. Lowe at 2:30 PM to be safe, with a break between the two depositions given that the proceedings would be conducted via Zoom. She asked whether that arrangement would work. Shortly thereafter, at 10:07:35 AM, Sarena replied that this would not work. She explained that if anything delayed the plaintiff’s deposition, Bryce and Aaron would not have enough time to complete their depositions within business hours. She expressed a reluctance to schedule something so close to the wire, especially during the holiday season, noting that the weather could be unpredictable. She proposed looking at additional dates with a 10:00–11:00 AM start time if available.

Earlier in the thread, the November 26 date remained a focal point, with the November 4 exchanges indicating a desire to arrange Mr. Johnson’s deposition at 1:00 PM and Mr. Lowe’s after that time, preferably by Zoom. The thread also contains a few standard confidentiality disclosures typical of electronic mail communications between counsel.

In sum, the parties have been negotiating dates for the depositions of Mr. Johnson and Mr. Lowe in late November 2024, with the latest proposals centering on a 1:00 PM start for Mr. Johnson and a subsequent deposition for Mr. Lowe on November 26, 2024, via Zoom. There remains concern about the duration and scheduling proximity of the two depositions, with the parties considering alternative dates and earlier start times (such as a 10:00–11:00 AM window) to avoid logistical conflicts and weather-related delays during the holiday season.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Johnson, and The Whaley Law Firm, regarding when Mr. Lowe and Mr. Johnson would be deposed, with a Zoom-based deposition planned for November 26, 2024.

On October 28, 2024, Sarena followed up again, indicating that they had requested deposition dates for Mr. Lowe on several occasions over the past 30 days but had not yet received any dates. She asked that dates be provided as soon as possible due to the upcoming holidays when calendars would fill.

By November 4, 2024, Mary replied with scheduling options. At 1:36 PM, she stated that Mr. Lowe was available on November 26 after 2:00 PM and suggested that they could depose Mr. Johnson at 1:00 PM and then depose Mr. Lowe afterward, in order not to go too late. Later the same day, at 2:38 PM, Mary clarified further that November 26 via Zoom was perfectly fine and asked whether the other side was comfortable with only one hour to depose Mr. Johnson, who they proposed to start at 1:00 PM. She reiterated that arrangement and the Zoom preference.

On November 7, 2024, at 10:03 AM (with the timestamp appearing as “10:03? AM,” continuing the thread), Mary wrote that she usually takes between 1 and 1.5 hours for depositions and proposed starting Mr. Lowe at 2:30 PM to provide a bit of a break between the two parties’ depositions. Shortly thereafter, at 10:08 AM on November 7, 2024, Sarena replied. She indicated that November 26, via Zoom, was perfectly fine and asked whether the parties were comfortable with only one hour to depose Mr. Johnson, who would start at 1:00 PM.

Later on November 7, 2024 at 3:11 PM (the timestamp shown as 15:11:44 +0000), Mary responded: “Ok. I will ask Mr. Lowe what he has available at that time.” This marked the latest development in the exchange, with the plan to confirm Mr. Lowe’s availability for the November 26 deposition date via Zoom and to finalize the start times.

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. Client: Charles T Johnson. This matter concerns Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe, listed as Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475, a matter arising from a motor vehicle accident on April 18, 2023.

In November 2024, the scheduling of depositions for the plaintiff, Mr. Charles Johnson, and for Mr. Robert Lowe was the subject of several email exchanges between the parties’ counsel. On November 12, 2024, Mary S. Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC wrote to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with copies to Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, and Amy Romine. She proposed two potential 11:00 a.m. deposition times for Mr. Lowe—either December 17 or December 18—and asked whether either date would work for Sarena and Mr. Johnson. In her message, Mary included her contact information and attached the standard confidentiality notice common to Dilbeck & Myers emails.

Mary’s message was followed by a thread in which Sarena Tuttle, who is a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, acknowledged the communication on November 7, 2024 with “Thank you so much,” and signed her messages with her updated contact details: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is her new email address.

Earlier on November 7, 2024, Mary had responded to Sarena by saying she would ask Mr. Lowe what dates he had available at that time. In a prior exchange on the same day, Sarena had written that if anything caused a delay in the Plaintiff’s deposition, Bryce and Aaron would not have enough time to complete their depositions within business hours, and she suggested looking at additional dates with a start time of 10:00 to 11:00 a.m., due to concerns about finishing within business hours, the holiday season, and unpredictable weather.

On November 7, 2024, Mary stated that she usually expected the depositions to take 1 to 1.5 hours, and proposed starting Mr. Lowe at 2:30 p.m. to be safe, noting that because the deposition would be conducted via Zoom, it would be easier to have a short break between the two depositions. She asked whether that arrangement would work for the other party and the client. Mary also reiterated her preference for Zoom, though she was willing to appear in person if that was the other party’s preference.

The thread also reveals an earlier back-and-forth beginning in October 2024. On October 23, 2024, Sarena requested dates for Mr. Lowe’s deposition, noting that Bryce had previously followed up on Mr. Lowe’s responses to the Plaintiff’s Discovery Request and that they had not yet received any dates for deposition. On October 28, 2024, Sarena reiterated the urgency of obtaining dates before the holidays, asking Mary to provide deposition dates as soon as possible given the approaching holiday calendar. This followed an earlier note from September 25, 2024, in which Bryce had sent an email following up on Mr. Lowe’s responses to the Plaintiff’s Discovery Request and had requested dates for Mr. Lowe’s availability for deposition in the following month.

Within the November 4, 2024 portion of the thread, Mary had proposed a plan for November 26: Mr. Lowe was said to be available after 2:00 p.m.; Mary suggested that Mr. Johnson could be deposed at 1:00 p.m. and Mr. Lowe could be deposed afterward, to avoid extending the day too late. She also stated a preference for Zoom but indicated willingness to appear in person if that was the other side’s preference. In response, on November 4, 2024 at 2:38 p.m., Sarena replied that November 26 via Zoom was perfectly fine and asked Mary to confirm whether starting Mr. Johnson at 1:00 p.m. and scheduling Mr. Lowe after 2:00 p.m. would be acceptable, given the plan for a one-hour deposition for Mr. Johnson starting at 1:00 p.m.

The overall record reflects a continuing effort to coordinate deposition dates for Mr. Johnson and Mr. Lowe, with multiple proposed times and formats (Zoom preferred, with a willingness to appear in person), an emphasis on avoiding overly long days, a preference to complete depositions within typical business hours, and consideration of the holiday season and weather. The parties’ contact details are as follows: Mary S. Johnson’s address is 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222, with telephone 502-595-6500 and fax 502-595-6504. Sarena Tuttle’s information lists The Whaley Law Firm at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line 502-357-9971, office line 502-583-4022 ext 104, and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new email address). Mary’s messages throughout the thread include confidentiality notices stating that the electronic transmission is for the named recipient and privileged or confidential, and instructing the recipient to delete and notify the sender if received in error.

In sum, the parties and counsel have been actively coordinating the scheduling of depositions for Mr. Charles Johnson and Mr. Robert Lowe in the Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475 case, with proposed dates in late November and December 2024, a preference for Zoom, stated deposition lengths of roughly one hour for Mr. Johnson and up to one-and-a-half hours for Mr. Lowe, and a plan to place the two depositions on the same day if feasible, while remaining mindful of calendar constraints and weather considerations.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe, Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475, the parties were coordinating the deposition schedule for the two individuals involved in the case: Mr. Charles T. Johnson and Mr. Robert Lowe. The client is Charles T. Johnson, and the case is identified as Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475. The scheduling communications occurred between The Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, with collaboration among several members of both teams.

On October 28, 2024, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Mary S. Johnson at Dilbeck & Myers, with Bryce Koon, Aaron Whaley, and Amy Romine CC’d. The message began with “Good afternoon Mrs. Johnson,” and stated that dates to depose Mr. Lowe had been requested on several occasions over the prior 30 days, but “to date, we still have” [text cut off]. The email was part of an ongoing effort to secure deposition dates for Mr. Lowe.

A follow-up exchange continued in early November. On November 4, 2024, Sarena replied with a short expression of thanks: “Thank you so much.” That same afternoon, Mary Johnson replied that Mr. Lowe was available on November 26 after 2:00 p.m., and suggested scheduling Mr. Johnson for a 1:00 p.m. deposition and then Mr. Lowe afterwards so the session would not run too late. She indicated a preference for Zoom, though she was willing to appear in person if that was the other party’s preference.

Later that same day, November 4, Mary proposed that arrangement, and on November 7, 2024 at 10:03 a.m. she stated that she typically expects each deposition to last 1 to 1.5 hours, so they could start Mr. Lowe at 2:30 p.m. to be safe and, since the depositions would be conducted via Zoom, suggested a brief break between the two sessions to keep within reasonable hours. In response, Sarena wrote on November 7 at 10:08 a.m. that this plan would not work, expressing concern that if anything delayed the Plaintiff’s deposition, Bryce and Aaron would not have enough time to complete their deposition within business hours. She noted the desire to avoid scheduling so close to the wire, especially during the holiday season and given unpredictable weather, and proposed looking at additional dates with a start time of 10:00–11:00 a.m. instead.

Mary followed up on November 7 at 10:11 a.m. by saying she would ask Mr. Lowe what he had available at that time. Sarena replied with a brief “Thank you so much” at 10:19 a.m., and the back-and-forth continued as the teams explored alternative time windows.

By November 12, 2024, Mary suggested that Mr. Lowe could do an 11:00 a.m. deposition on December 17 or December 18, and asked whether either date would work for Mr. Johnson as well. In response later that same day, Sarena confirmed that December 17, 2024 starting at 11:00 a.m. via Zoom would work perfectly, and she stated she would finalize the date and get it on the calendar. She closed with thanks and provided her contact details.

Thus, after multiple exchanges and scheduling considerations—balancing preferred times, the duration of each deposition (approximately 1–1.5 hours for Mr. Johnson, with the possibility of back-to-back sessions for Mr. Lowe), and the realities of Zoom versus in-person proceedings—the deposition was set for December 17, 2024 at 11:00 a.m. via Zoom. The parties intended to finalize and place the date on the calendar accordingly.

In November 2024, scheduling discussions were exchanged between Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC (attorneys for Mr. Johnson) and The Whaley Law Firm (attorneys for Mr. Lowe) regarding the deposition of Charles Johnson and of Mr. Lowe in the Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475 matter. The thread began with an email from Mary S. Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers on November 4, 2024. She proposed that Mr. Lowe be deposed after 2:00 PM on November 26, 2024, and that Mr. Johnson be deposed at 1:00 PM the same day, noting a preference for Zoom but offering to appear in person if that was the other side’s preference. She also indicated that she usually schedules depositions to run about 1 to 1.5 hours, and she suggested starting Mr. Lowe at 2:30 PM to be safe so there would be a bit of a break between the two zoom depositions.

On November 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm responded, thanking Mary. In a subsequent chain, Mary replied that she would ask Mr. Lowe what he had available at that time. Later on November 7, Sarena replied that if anything should delay the Plaintiff’s deposition, Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley would not have enough time to complete their deposition within business hours. She expressed concern about scheduling something so close to the wire, especially during the holiday season and given unpredictable weather, and suggested looking at additional dates when there was a 10:00–11:00 AM start time available.

Also on November 7, 2024, Mary indicated that she usually takes 1–1.5 hours for a deposition and reiterated the 2:30 PM start for Mr. Lowe to be safe. The exchange included standard signatures for both sides with their addresses and contact information.

On November 12, 2024, Mary asked, “Would you want to do Mr. Johnson at 9:30? And we are doing Zoom, correct?” She provided her contact details and again included the confidentiality notice that accompanies Dilbeck & Myers emails. In response, Sarena noted that December 17, 2024, starting at 11:00 AM via Zoom would work perfectly and that she would get this finalized and on the calendar.

Later that same day, November 12, 2024, Mary wrote back: “Ok… he can do 11 am on Dec 17th or 18th. Would either of those work for you and Mr. Johnson?” She again provided her office address, phone, fax, and new email address in her signature.

The thread confirms that the parties settled on December 17, 2024 at 11:00 AM via Zoom as a viable deposition slot, with the option of December 18, 2024 if needed. Sarena stated that the December 17 slot via Zoom “works perfectly” and that she would finalize and place it on the calendar. The communications include the usual confidentiality notices and detailed contact information for the involved lawyers, as well as a record of the evolving scheduling considerations and preferences (Zoom preferred, potential conflicts with back-to-back depositions, and the desire to avoid delays during the holiday season and inclement weather).

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023
Client: Charles T Johnson

In the matter of Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe, Jeff Cir 24-CI-002475, the Whaley Law Firm and Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC coordinated deposition scheduling for the plaintiff, Charles T. Johnson, in a motor vehicle accident case dated April 18, 2023. The communication thread began with scheduling efforts for a deposition via Zoom, with the parties considering a December 2024 date and aiming to allocate sufficient time for all participants.

On November 4, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, indicated that November 26, 2024, via Zoom, would be perfectly fine starting at 1:00 p.m. for a one-hour deposition of Mr. Johnson. She also noted her new email address. Mary S. Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers replied that she would check with Mr. Lowe about availability.

Two days later, on November 7, 2024, Mary suggested starting Mr. Lowe at 2:30 p.m. to provide a safer buffer, since she typically takes 1 to 1.5 hours for a deposition and the sessions would be conducted by Zoom with a break between the two. Sarena replied that scheduling something so close to the wire could leave Bryce Koon and Aaron Whaley with insufficient time to complete their depositions within business hours, especially given the holiday season and unpredictable weather. She proposed looking at additional dates with a start window of 10:00 to 11:00 a.m. for better scheduling flexibility. Mary agreed to check Mr. Lowe’s availability at that time.

On November 12, 2024, Mary proposed that Mr. Lowe could do 11:00 a.m. on December 17th or 18th. Later that same day, Sarena confirmed that December 17, 2024, starting at 11:00 a.m. via Zoom, would work perfectly and that she would finalize the arrangement and place it on the calendar. Mary then asked again about a potential 9:30 a.m. start for Mr. Johnson and confirmed that the deposition would be conducted via Zoom. In response, Sarena reaffirmed that December 17, 2024, at 11:00 a.m. via Zoom would work, and she would proceed to finalize the scheduling.

Signatures and contact details relevant to the correspondents appeared in the exchanges: Sarena M. Tuttle, listed as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with address 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting a new email address). Mary S. Johnson’s contact information was listed as 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, KY 40222; phone (502) 595-6500; fax (502) 595-6504. The exchanges repeatedly carried standard confidentiality notices typical of electronic communications between the named parties.

In summary, after a series of scheduling discussions in early November 2024, the plan was finalized for the deposition of Mr. Charles Johnson on December 17, 2024, at 11:00 a.m., to be conducted via Zoom, with the calendar to be updated accordingly.

episodes.natural_language:
The Charles T. Johnson motor vehicle accident matter against Robert Lowe, Jefferson County case 24-CI-002475, involves the client Charles T. Johnson in a dispute arising from the April 18, 2023 incident. The case file for this matter is tracked under the name Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023, and the communications below reflect negotiations and settlement discussions between counsel.

On April 29, 2025, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Mary S. Johnson of Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, regarding the Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe matter. In his message, Bryce suggested exploring mediation for the case, noting that while the firm was prepared to continue litigating, mediation might still be productive. He asked Mary to share her thoughts on mediation, and he offered to discuss logistics and potential mediators if there was interest. The email was addressed to Mary with cc’s to the Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 Filevine project email address and to Sarena Tuttle, and it included The Whaley Law Firm’s standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Mary S. Johnson responded to Bryce on May 9, 2025, around 12:20 PM. She indicated that she is generally open to mediation but prefers to attempt informal negotiations first to see if a settlement is possible. She noted that the parties have opposing views of liability, which would likely pose a stumbling block. She suggested that if Mr. Johnson does not expect the settlement to be reflective of a liability assessment in his favor, they might be able to reach a resolution without mediation to save him money on the settlement. She asked Bryce for his thoughts on this approach and whether mediation should be pursued, given the potential liability disagreement. Mary included her contact details: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; phone 502-595-6500; fax 502-595-6504. Her message also carried the standard privileged-notice language common to such communications.

Bryce Koon replied to Mary on May 9, 2025 at 12:44:33 PM (GMT-04:00). He acknowledged her response, stating, “Understood. Thank you for getting back to me.” He said he would talk with his client early the following week and would attempt to provide a demand shortly thereafter. His signature followed, along with The Whaley Law Firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and his contact information (phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-237-3207). The reply, like prior messages, contained the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer.

Case: Charles-T-Johnson-MVA-4-18-2023. The client is Charles T. Johnson, involved in a motor vehicle accident case alleged against Robert Lowe, docketed in Jefferson County as 24-CI-002475.

On July 21, 2025, at 10:35:21 a.m. Eastern Time, Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel for the opposing side regarding Charles Johnson v. Robert Lowe (Jefferson 24-CI-002475). The subject line mirrored the case caption. In the body of the message, Koon stated that he had discussed the matter with his client and wanted to follow up to see whether the opposing counsel had an offer in light of a prior email. He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and listed the firm’s phone number as (502) 365-5043 and fax as (502) 237-3207. The message was sent to Mary S. Johnson at Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC, with a Filevine Project email address included in the cc line: Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 - Filevine Project Email Address, CharlesJohnsonZ3709312@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com, and included cc to the case file for visibility. The email contained the customary attorney‑client privilege disclaimer stating the message was intended only for the named recipient and that improper receipt should be reported; it advised no waiver of privilege and instructed not to use or forward the information.

Earlier, on April 29, 2025, at 2:28 PM, Bryce Koon had emailed Mary S. Johnson regarding the same matter. In that message, he wrote to inquire whether the opposing party would be open to exploring mediation. He acknowledged that both sides were prepared to proceed with litigation but suggested mediation might be productive. He invited Mary to share her thoughts and, if there was interest, to discuss logistics and potential mediators. This message also carried the standard confidentiality and privilege notice and was cc’d to the same Filevine project email address for the Charles Johnson MVA 4/18/2023 file and to Sarena Tuttle, with the Whaley Law Firm again listed as the sender and The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details included in the signature.

Mary S. Johnson replied on May 9, 2025, at about 12:20 p.m. She indicated she was always open to mediation but preferred attempting informal negotiations first to see if a settlement was possible. She noted that the parties likely held opposite views of liability, which would present a stumbling block. However, she suggested that if Mr. Johnson did not expect a settlement reflecting a liability determination in his favor, it might be possible to resolve the matter without mediation to save on settlement costs. She asked for thoughts on whether to pursue informal negotiations first rather than mediation. Her message included her contact information: 8005 Lyndon Centre Way, Suite 201, Louisville, Kentucky 40222; phone (502) 595-6500; fax (502) 595-6504. As with the other emails, a confidentiality disclaimer noted that the transmission was for the named recipient and warned against unauthorized copying or forwarding, with instructions to delete and notify if received in error and to contact Dilbeck & Myers, PLLC at (502) 595-6500 to correct any address record.

In summary, the communication history in this case comprises an April 29, 2025 mediation outreach from W. Bryce Koon to Mary S. Johnson, proposing mediation as a productive path while acknowledging ongoing litigation, followed by a May 9, 2025 response from Mary Johnson advocating initial informal negotiations due to likely liability disagreements, and a July 21, 2025 follow-up from Bryce Koon asking whether there was any offer in light of the prior exchange. All messages included standard privilege and confidentiality notices and were cc’d to the relevant Filevine project address and participants.
